user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 is: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of fill_v1_form:
```c
static enum MHD_Result
fill_v1_form (const void *cls,
              const char *mime,
              struct Session *session,
              struct MHD_Connection *connection)
{
  enum MHD_Result ret;
  size_t slen;
  char *reply;
  struct MHD_Response *response;
  (void) cls; /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */

  slen = strlen (MAIN_PAGE) + strlen (session->value_1);
  reply = malloc (slen + 1);
  if (NULL == reply)
    return MHD_NO;
  snprintf (reply,
            slen + 1,
            MAIN_PAGE,
            session->value_1);
  /* return static form */
  response =
    MHD_create_response_from_buffer_with_free_callback (slen,
                                                        (void *) reply,
                                                        &free);
  if (NULL == response)
  {
    free (reply);
    return MHD_NO;
  }
  add_session_cookie (session, response);
  if (MHD_YES !=
      MHD_add_response_header (response,
                               MHD_HTTP_HEADER_CONTENT_ENCODING,
                               mime))
  {
    fprintf (stderr,
             "Failed to set content encoding header!\n");
  }
  ret = MHD_queue_response (connection,
                            MHD_HTTP_OK,
                            response);
  MHD_destroy_response (response);
  return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No suspicious fragments found for Rule 17.2 (no self-calls). Reasoning:
- There is no direct call to fill_v1_form anywhere in the function body.
- No function pointer referring to fill_v1_form is passed; the only function pointer passed is &free (the standard library free), which cannot call fill_v1_form.
- All called functions from this fragment are either standard library functions (strlen, malloc, snprintf, free, fprintf) or libmicrohttpd helpers (MHD_create_response_from_buffer_with_free_callback, MHD_add_response_header, MHD_queue_response, MHD_destroy_response) or add_session_cookie. None of these calls in this fragment provide evidence that they call back into fill_v1_form (they are not passed a pointer to this function).
- There are no global/static function-pointer variables or assignments in this fragment that could create an indirect call chain back to fill_v1_form.
- The function is declared static, but that only limits linkage and does not imply recursion.

Given the provided code only, there is no indication of direct or indirect self-calling; therefore no code fragments need further investigation for Rule 17.2. If callers/implementations of add_session_cookie or the MHD_* functions (not shown here) contain callbacks that could invoke this handler, those external implementations would need review, but there is no evidence of such from the shown fragment.
